TLCOrganization.showAs: Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan

preface.p: Pakistan AML/CFT legal corpus for the Momentum EZ compliance stack. Consolidates key provisions from the Anti-Money Laundering Act, 2010 (Act VII of 2010), the Anti-Terrorism Act, 1997 (Act XXVII of 1997, CFT provisions), the SECP AML/CFT Regulations, 2018, and the SBP AML/CFT Regulations for Banks. Thresholds and requirements reflect the legal position as of January 2024.

content.p: In this Act, unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context:

item.p: "financial institution" means a banking company, a non-banking finance company, a modaraba, a leasing company, an insurance company, a securities broker, a foreign exchange dealer, a money service business, a payment system operator, or any other entity as the Federal Government may by notification declare to be a financial institution for the purposes of this Act.

"reporting entity" means a financial institution, a designated non-financial business or profession, or any other person or entity as the Federal Government may by notification prescribe as a reporting entity.

"suspicious transaction" means a transaction, whether or not made in cash, which, to a person acting in good faith: (i) gives rise to a reasonable suspicion that it may involve the proceeds of an offence regardless of the value of the transaction; or (ii) appears to be made in circumstances of unusual or unjustified complexity; or (iii) appears to have no economic rationale or lawful purpose; or (iv) gives rise to a reasonable suspicion that it may involve financing of terrorism or a proscribed organization.

"beneficial owner" means the natural person who ultimately owns or controls a customer or on whose behalf a transaction or activity is being conducted, and includes any person who exercises ultimate effective control over a legal person or arrangement.

"designated non-financial business or profession" means: (i) a real estate agent; (ii) a dealer in precious metals or precious stones; (iii) a lawyer, notary, or other independent legal professional when preparing for or carrying out transactions for a client concerning buying and selling of real estate, managing client money or assets, managing bank or securities accounts, or creation or management of legal persons or arrangements; (iv) a trust and company service provider; (v) an accountant; or (vi) any other business or profession as the Federal Government may by notification prescribe.

"predicate offence" means any offence the commission of which generates proceeds that may become the subject of an offence under Section 3 of this Act, and includes offences set out in the Schedule to this Act, including but not limited to fraud, forgery, corruption, drug trafficking, kidnapping, extortion, smuggling, tax evasion, and any offence punishable under the Anti-Terrorism Act, 1997.

content.p: A person shall be guilty of the offence of money laundering if the person:

item.p: acquires, possesses, uses, converts, or transfers property knowing or having reason to believe that such property is the proceeds of a predicate offence;

conceals or disguises the true nature, source, location, disposition, movement, or ownership of property knowing or having reason to believe that such property is the proceeds of a predicate offence; or
holds, conceals, or facilitates any dealing in property knowing or having reason to believe that such property is the proceeds of a predicate offence.

content.p: It shall not be necessary to establish a conviction for the predicate offence in order to prove the offence of money laundering.
The offence of money laundering extends to property derived directly or indirectly from the predicate offence, including income, profits, or other benefits derived from the proceeds.

Whoever commits the offence of money laundering shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than one year but may extend to ten years and shall also be liable to a fine which may extend to PKR 1,000,000 (one million rupees), or twice the value of the property involved in the offence, whichever is greater.

Where the offence of money laundering has been committed by a body corporate, every person who at the time the offence was committed was in charge of and was responsible to the body corporate for the conduct of the business of the body corporate, as well as the body corporate, shall be deemed to be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.
Property involved in or derived from money laundering shall be liable to forfeiture to the Federal Government, regardless of whether any person has been convicted of the offence.
Every reporting entity shall carry out customer due diligence (CDD) measures when:

item.p: establishing a business relationship;
there is a suspicion of money laundering or financing of terrorism; or
the reporting entity has doubts about the veracity or adequacy of previously obtained customer identification data.

content.p: CDD measures shall include:

item.p: Identity verification: identifying the customer and verifying the customer's identity using reliable, independent source documents, data, or information. For natural persons, this shall include the customer's full name, date of birth, residential address, and Computerised National Identity Card (CNIC) number or passport number. For legal persons, this shall include the entity's name, registration number, registered address, and details of directors or partners.

Beneficial ownership: identifying the beneficial owner and taking reasonable measures to verify the identity of the beneficial owner, such that the reporting entity is satisfied that it knows who the beneficial owner is, including for legal persons and legal arrangements, understanding the ownership and control structure.
Purpose and nature: understanding and, as appropriate, obtaining information on the purpose and intended nature of the business relationship.

Ongoing monitoring: conducting ongoing due diligence on the business relationship and scrutiny of transactions undertaken throughout the course of that relationship to ensure that the transactions being conducted are consistent with the reporting entity's knowledge of the customer, their business and risk profile, including where necessary the source of funds.

content.p: A reporting entity shall apply a risk-based approach to CDD. Where the risk of money laundering or terrorist financing is higher, enhanced measures shall be taken; where the risk is lower, simplified measures may be permitted, subject to conditions prescribed by the relevant supervisory authority.

section.heading: Enhanced Due Diligence for Politically Exposed Persons and High-Risk Countries

content.p: Every reporting entity shall apply enhanced due diligence (EDD) measures, in addition to the CDD measures required under Section 6, in the following circumstances:

item.p: Politically Exposed Persons (PEPs): where the customer or the beneficial owner is a PEP, whether domestic or foreign, the reporting entity shall: (i) obtain senior management approval before establishing or continuing the business relationship; (ii) take reasonable measures to establish the source of wealth and source of funds; and (iii) conduct enhanced ongoing monitoring of the business relationship.

High-risk countries: where the customer, beneficial owner, or transaction involves a country identified by the FATF as high-risk or under increased monitoring (grey list or black list), the reporting entity shall apply counter-measures proportionate to the risks, which may include: enhanced scrutiny of the business relationship; requiring additional documentation on the source and purpose of funds; and reporting the relationship or transaction to the FMU.

Correspondent banking: for cross-border correspondent banking relationships, the reporting entity shall: gather sufficient information about the respondent institution to understand the nature of its business; determine from publicly available information the reputation of the institution and the quality of supervision; assess the respondent institution's AML/CFT controls; and obtain senior management approval before establishing new correspondent relationships.

content.p: Where a reporting entity has reasonable grounds to suspect that a transaction, attempted transaction, or funds are the proceeds of an offence or are related to or to be used for financing of terrorism, the reporting entity shall as soon as possible but not later than seven working days submit a suspicious transaction report (STR) to the Financial Monitoring Unit (FMU).

The STR shall contain such particulars as the FMU may prescribe, including but not limited to: the identity of the persons involved; the nature and details of the transaction; the grounds for suspicion; and any other information that may assist the FMU in its analysis.
STRs shall be filed through the goAML portal maintained by the FMU, or through such other electronic means as the FMU may prescribe.
The obligation to submit an STR applies regardless of the amount of the transaction and regardless of whether the transaction was completed or attempted.

Every reporting entity shall submit a currency transaction report (CTR) to the FMU in respect of every cash transaction exceeding PKR 2,000,000 (two million rupees) or its equivalent in foreign currency, whether the transaction is conducted as a single transaction or as several transactions that appear to be linked.
CTRs shall be submitted within fifteen days of the end of the calendar month in which the transaction was conducted, through the goAML portal or such other means as the FMU may prescribe.

Where a reporting entity suspects that a transaction has been structured (i.e., deliberately split into amounts below the CTR threshold to avoid reporting), the reporting entity shall also file an STR under Section 7.
Every financial institution ordering a cross-border wire transfer shall ensure that the wire transfer is accompanied by the following originator information:

item.p: the name of the originator;
the originator's account number or, in the absence of an account, a unique transaction reference number;
the originator's address, CNIC number, customer identification number, or date and place of birth.

content.p: For wire transfers exceeding USD 1,000 or its equivalent in other currencies, the ordering financial institution shall verify the identity of the originator prior to execution of the transfer and include the following beneficiary information:

item.p: the name of the beneficiary; and
the beneficiary's account number or, in the absence of an account, a unique transaction reference number.

content.p: The requirements of this section shall be applied in compliance with FATF Recommendation 16 and are applicable to wire transfers using SWIFT MT103 messages, ISO 20022 pacs.008 messages, or any other payment messaging standard.

Intermediary financial institutions in a payment chain shall ensure that all originator and beneficiary information accompanying a wire transfer is retained with the transfer. Failure to include required originator or beneficiary information shall constitute grounds for rejection or suspension of the transfer.

Every reporting entity shall maintain the following records for a period of not less than five years from the date of completion of the transaction or from the date of termination of the business relationship, whichever is later:

item.p: all records obtained through CDD measures, including copies of identification documents, account files, and business correspondence;
all transaction records, including details sufficient to reconstruct individual transactions so as to provide, if necessary, evidence for prosecution of criminal activity; and
all internal reports, risk assessments, and analysis related to STRs and CTRs.

content.p: Records may be maintained in electronic form provided the reporting entity can produce legible hard copies upon request by the FMU, a supervisory authority, or a law enforcement agency within a reasonable time.

The FMU or the relevant supervisory authority may, by order, require a reporting entity to retain specified records for a period longer than five years in connection with an ongoing investigation or proceeding.
No reporting entity, and no director, officer, employee, or agent of a reporting entity, shall disclose to any person the fact that:

item.p: an STR or related information has been or is being filed with the FMU;
an investigation into money laundering or financing of terrorism is being or may be conducted; or
any order for freezing, seizure, or forfeiture of property has been made or is being sought under this Act.

content.p: Any person who contravenes this section shall be guilty of an offence and shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to a fine which may extend to PKR 500,000.

This section does not apply to disclosure: (a) between financial institutions within the same group for AML/CFT compliance purposes; (b) between a reporting entity and its legal adviser in connection with seeking legal advice; or (c) between competent authorities in the performance of their functions under this Act.
Every regulated person shall adopt a risk-based approach to combating money laundering and financing of terrorism. This shall include:

item.p: documenting the risk assessment and making it available to the SECP upon request;
classifying customers into risk categories (low, medium, and high) based on the risk assessment; and
applying CDD measures commensurate with the identified risk level, with enhanced measures for higher-risk relationships and simplified measures permitted for lower-risk relationships.

content.p: The risk assessment shall be updated at least annually, or more frequently in the event of a material change in the regulated person's business or risk profile, or in the event of a new emerging risk identified by the SECP, FATF, or FMU.
CDD measures to be applied by regulated persons shall be proportionate to the risk associated with the customer relationship:

item.p: Simplified CDD (low risk): for customers assessed as low risk, the regulated person may verify the identity of the customer and beneficial owner after the establishment of the business relationship, provided that: the risk of money laundering has been effectively managed; verification is completed within 30 days of account opening; and the regulated person has adopted procedures to limit the number and types of transactions that can be performed prior to verification.

Standard CDD (medium risk): for customers assessed as medium risk, verification of identity shall be completed before or at the time of establishing the business relationship. Source of funds documentation shall be obtained where the transaction exceeds PKR 5,000,000.

Enhanced CDD (high risk): for customers assessed as high risk, including PEPs, customers from FATF grey-list or black-list jurisdictions, and complex or unusual transactions, the regulated person shall: obtain senior management approval; establish the source of wealth and source of funds through documentary evidence; and apply enhanced ongoing monitoring with transaction review at least monthly.

content.p: Every regulated person shall conduct ongoing monitoring of all business relationships and transactions to ensure that they are consistent with the regulated person's knowledge of the customer and the customer's business and risk profile.
The frequency of monitoring reviews shall be commensurate with the customer's risk classification:

item.p: Low-risk customers: annual review of the business relationship and transaction patterns.
Medium-risk customers: quarterly review of transaction patterns and periodic re-verification of customer information.
High-risk customers: monthly review of all transactions; automated transaction monitoring alerts where available; and senior management review of the relationship at least every six months.

content.p: Where ongoing monitoring reveals unusual or suspicious activity, the regulated person shall conduct further analysis and, where the suspicion is confirmed, file an STR with the FMU within the prescribed timeframe.

Every regulated person shall file STRs with the FMU within seven working days of forming a suspicion, through the goAML portal. The compliance officer shall be responsible for the decision to file and the quality of information contained in the STR.

The STR shall include, at a minimum: the identity of the persons involved; account details and transaction history relevant to the suspicion; the nature and date of the suspicious activity; the reason for suspicion; and any supporting documents or information.

Where the regulated person identifies a transaction that may relate to the financing of terrorism or a proscribed organization, the STR shall be filed immediately and the regulated person shall not proceed with the transaction until authorized by the FMU.
Every regulated person shall appoint a compliance officer at a sufficiently senior level, with the following requirements:

item.p: the appointment shall be approved by the board of directors or equivalent senior management body;
the compliance officer shall have direct access to the board and to the regulated person's customer records and transaction information;
the compliance officer shall have completed FATF-aligned AML/CFT training and shall undergo refresher training at least annually; and
the compliance officer shall be responsible for ensuring the regulated person's compliance with the Act, these Regulations, and any directions issued by the SECP or the FMU.

content.p: The name and contact details of the compliance officer shall be communicated to the SECP and the FMU within 30 days of appointment or any change in appointment.

Every regulated person shall retain all CDD records, transaction records, internal analysis, and STR-related records for a minimum of five years from the date of the transaction or from the date of termination of the business relationship, whichever is later.

Records must be sufficient to permit reconstruction of individual transactions, including the amounts and types of currencies involved, and must be available to the SECP, the FMU, and law enforcement authorities upon request without undue delay.

part.heading: SBP AML/CFT Regulations for Banks -- Key Thresholds and Requirements

content.p: Every bank and financial institution supervised by the State Bank of Pakistan shall file a CTR with the FMU for every cash transaction (deposit, withdrawal, currency exchange, or transfer) exceeding PKR 2,000,000 (two million rupees) or its equivalent in foreign currency, whether conducted as a single transaction or as multiple transactions that appear to be linked or structured.

For cross-border wire transfers, full originator information (name, account number, address or national identity number, and date and place of birth) is required for all transfers exceeding USD 1,000 or its equivalent in other currencies, in accordance with FATF Recommendation 16.

For wire transfers of USD 1,000 or below, the ordering institution shall include the originator's name and account number (or unique transaction reference). The beneficiary institution shall have effective risk-based procedures for identifying wire transfers that lack required originator information.

Enhanced monitoring of a customer identified as a Politically Exposed Person (PEP) shall continue for the entire duration of the business relationship, regardless of changes in the customer's political status. A former PEP shall continue to be subject to enhanced monitoring for a period determined by the bank's risk assessment, which shall be not less than twelve months after the person ceases to hold the relevant position, and indefinitely where the residual risk remains elevated.
Banks shall screen all existing customers against updated PEP lists (domestic and international) at least quarterly, or upon notification by the FMU or SBP of additions to the lists.

Banks shall file STRs with the FMU within seven working days of forming a suspicion, through the goAML portal maintained by the FMU. The STR shall be prepared by the branch compliance officer and reviewed and approved by the head office compliance function before submission.

Where the suspicion relates to financing of terrorism, the bank shall file the STR immediately and shall freeze the relevant account or transaction pending instruction from the FMU, in accordance with the provisions of the Anti-Terrorism Act, 1997 and any freezing orders issued under United Nations Security Council Resolutions.
Banks shall maintain internal records of all STRs filed, including the outcome of the FMU's analysis where communicated, for a minimum of five years.
